docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''C-Sections and the Real Crime,'' by Rebecca Johnson (Op-Ed, April 12): It's imperative that women learn all they can during pregnancy about the risks and benefits of Caesarean versus vaginal birth.
docs.abstract: Letter from Maureen Corry of Maternity Center Assn on risks of Caesarean deliveries
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''C-Sections and the Real Crime,'' by Rebecca Johnson (Op-Ed, April 12):    It's imperative that women learn all they can during pregnancy about the risks and benefits of Caesarean versus vaginal birth.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I agree that the medical establishment cannot ''predict with certainty the best course of action for a fetus in distress'' (Op-Ed, April 12). Indeed, the outcome of treating any medical condition is never certain.
docs.abstract: Dr Fikry B Salib letter agrees that medical establishment cannot predict with certainty best course of action for fetus in distress, but notes that this is true of any medical treatment
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    I agree that the medical establishment cannot ''predict with certainty the best course of action for a fetus in distress'' (Op-Ed, April 12). Indeed, the outcome of treating any medical condition is never certain.

docs.lead_paragraph: A CREATIVE writing class (of all places) is the setting of New York's hot political drama of the moment, ''Mrs. Farnsworth,'' currently playing at the Flea Theater in a sold-out production directed by Jim Simpson and starring Sigourney Weaver and John Lithgow as a blue-blood married couple. A. R. Gurney's new play -- his second of the season after Lincoln Center Theater's ''Big Bill,'' about the gay tennis player Bill Tilden -- asks the question: to what lengths should concerned liberals go to protest an administration that they believe is hurting the country?
docs.abstract: Excerpt from A R Gurney's play Mrs Farnsworth, directed by Jim Simpson and starring Sigourney Weaver and John Lithgow at Flea Theater; photo

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are the Stansburys, now. Twelve weeks have passed since their youngest was killed by an officer of the law, 11 weeks since he was buried, 8 since a grand jury declined to indict the policeman and 5 since the family announced a lawsuit against the city. The television cameras are long gone. Grandmother paces before a precinct station house in Brooklyn, pressing a poster against the glass door and hollering, ''Big fat pigs!''

headline.main: Grief in a Police Killing Follows a Public Script; As Furor Dies Down, Teenager's Family Is Left to Suffer in Private

docs.abstract: Family of Timothy Stansbury Jr continues to grieve, rage and demand justice three months after he was shot to death by Police Officer Richard S Neri Jr while patroling rooftop of housing project in Brooklyn; demonstrations continue, but news coverage steadily dwindles; US attorney's office is reviewing evidence in case now that grand jury has declined to indict Neri; family intends to sue city; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Here are the Stansburys, now. Twelve weeks have passed since their youngest was killed by an officer of the law, 11 weeks since he was buried, 8 since a grand jury declined to indict the policeman and 5 since the family announced a lawsuit against...

docs.lead_paragraph: The state's Supreme Court ruled that a Food and Drug Administration label warning pregnant women of the dangers of nicotine patches trumps a stricter state-mandated label required by a 1986 voter-approved proposition. The court's unanimous decision, which reversed an appeals court ruling, said a federal warning label should be used in place of the state warning label only when the federal warning was more balanced.

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Ruling On Nicotine-Patch Labels

docs.abstract: California Supreme Court rules Food and Drug Administration label warning pregnant women of dangers of nicotine patches trumps stricter state-mandated label (S)
docs.snippet: The state's Supreme Court ruled that a Food and Drug Administration label warning pregnant women of the dangers of nicotine patches trumps a stricter state-mandated label required by a 1986 voter-approved proposition. The court's unanimous decision,...

docs.lead_paragraph: By dawn Wednesday, Atara Sasoon had already become a mother in a most remarkable fashion -- giving birth to her son in the back seat of a car while her husband, Binyamin, drove his new family to the hospital. Then she became a widow.

headline.main: Crash Kills Man Moments After Son Is Born in Car

docs.abstract: Binyamin Sasoon dies in car crash in Brick Township, NJ, just moments after his wife, Atara, gives birth to son in back seat of car; Patrick Schlagenhaft, passing driver, saves mother and gets baby breathing with help from 911 operator; photo (M)
docs.snippet: By dawn Wednesday, Atara Sasoon had already become a mother in a most remarkable fashion -- giving birth to her son in the back seat of a car while her husband, Binyamin, drove his new family to the hospital.    Then she became a widow.

byline.original: By RICHARD LEZIN JONES and MATTHEW C. McCUE; Richard Lezin Jones reported for this article from Newark and Matthew C. McCue from Brick Township, Lakewood and Neptune. Yaniv Gafner contributed reporting from Newark
